page.title: 18 Rushden Water Tower
page.content: The water tank is 100ft high,(there are 108 rungs to the top) domed and in a 35 year old, octagonal building with windows in alternate sides. No-one works there but the water is tested weekly and pumps regularly checked (the tank is cleaned 4 yearly). A house uses 70 to 90 gals. per day. The tank handles 500000 gals. per day, although the tank is not that big, water is always being pumped through it. The pump operates automatically. The water comes from Grafham Water, a huge reservoir in Cambridgeshire. It is cleaned, pumped down a main pipe, a branch of which supplies Rushden. The tower only has enough pressure to supply part of Rushden. An underground reservoir next to the tower supplies the lowest part of the town Several other towers serving nearby towns, can be seen from the tank's top.
